head.title: Pipe Bomb Explodes at City Hall in Spokane

hedline.hl1: Pipe Bomb Explodes at City Hall in Spokane

block.p: A pipe bomb packed with three-inch nails exploded in a doorway of Spokane City Hall before dawn this morning, the police said. The building was unoccupied, and no one was injured.

Residents of nearby apartments reported hearing a boom about 3 A.M., and workers discovered damaged doors about 6:30 A.M., Chief Terry Mangan of the Spokane police said. Shrapnel in the area appeared to be from "a fairly large pipe bomb," he said.
A pipe bomb packed with three-inch nails exploded in a doorway of Spokane City Hall before dawn this morning, the police said. The building was unoccupied, and no one was injured.

Residents of nearby apartments reported hearing a boom about 3 A.M., and workers discovered damaged doors about 6:30 A.M., Chief Terry Mangan of the Spokane police said. Shrapnel in the area appeared to be from "a fairly large pipe bomb," he said.
The building's heavy oak doors apparently deflected the blast away from the building, and nails ended up more than a block away in Riverfront Park, Chief Mangan said.
"If this had been a crowded day, if we had had a lot of people out here, we would have had very, very serious and very, very many injuries," he said.
No one claimed responsibility for the bombing, but Chief Mangan said the police were investigating some graffiti on the building.
Earlier this month there were bombings at a newspaper office and a bank in the Spokane area.
A bomb squad searched City Hall for other explosives today while people who work there were sent to wait at the Spokane Arena about three blocks away.

The Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms and the Federal Bureau of Investigation were called in, and the authorities searched other municipal buildings, bridges and communication sites as a precaution. No other devices were found, Chief Mangan said.

On April 1, men in ski masks and fatigues set off a small bomb while robbing a bank in suburban Spokane Valley. Minutes earlier, another pipe bomb had exploded outside a nearby office of The Spokesman-Review.
